body: The church has been filled with weak men who have shirked their role in their families, their societies and their country. They have been taught a feminized Christ and, reading the word, they commit it to memory but have no understanding. It is as the saying goes: "A nation who makes a great distinction between its warriors and it scholars will have its laws made by cowards and its wars fought by fools.". The founders of this great nation were men of God yet they took up arms against tyranny, and any man who stands where we stand today and doesn't see tyranny at their doorstep is an idiot.
body_html: The church has been filled with weak men who have shirked their role in their families, their societies and their country. They have been taught a feminized Christ and, reading the word, they commit it to memory but have no understanding. It is as the saying goes: "A nation who makes a great distinction between its warriors and it scholars will have its laws made by cowards and its wars fought by fools.". The founders of this great nation were men of God yet they took up arms against tyranny, and any man who stands where we stand today and doesn't see tyranny at their doorstep is an idiot.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: Likely many of the churches feel this way. Western churches suffer greatly from being feminized, and the women really run the show. The church I used to attend is decorated with frilly doilies and flowers, the women have a dozen different events and classes through the week and the last I heard they were ordaining them as pastors. I left a few years ago when we men were relegated to a tiny back room for the men's group while the women had the run of the joint. The thing is, this is the experience I've had at the past few churches I have attended long term and the churches I have visited. Women have been elevated in the chain of command above men, which is not biblical. Women ascribe to "experience" more than men do and are more sympathetic to perceived injustice and slights, ergo, the church has adopted the culture as a baseline for what is right and filters scripture through it where they can. In places where they cannot, ie: really bad sins like murder, they stand, but society as a whole also sees those things as bad. Things like abortion, divorce and adultery get a pass, though, because they are widely accepted by society as a whole, mostly by women, and scripture can be twisted to support them, or ignored where need be.

Women ascribe to "experience" more than men do and are more sympathetic to perceived injustice and slights, ergo, the church has adopted the culture as a baseline for what is right and filters scripture through it where they can. In places where they cannot, ie: really bad sins like murder, they stand, but society as a whole also sees those things as bad. Things like abortion, divorce and adultery get a pass, though, because they are widely accepted by society as a whole, mostly by women, and scripture can be twisted to support them, or ignored where need be.

body: I thank God that I have never had to spend any length of time in a church like that.  I've had to leave when things were heading in that direction and look elsewhere a few times, though.  Sometimes they are hard to find, but there are a few groups still out there.

body:
I think home groups should be where the church is meeting right now, bit unlike when the church began. I know some youtube people don't think "all churches are businesses and want your money", but I think they end up like that. As soon as a church starts to buy property and equipment and take on a staff then keeping money in the coffers becomes a high priority, and Christ can get pushed to the back shelf. And he does, because we see Western churches catering to their best customers! Women! Men don't spend a ton of money on religious stuff. A bible and maybe some studies. Women spend far more AND control where the money goes in a lot of homes. When you pay 10k a month in expenses you need to keep those tithes rolling in! The church I spoke of above once sent out letters urging people to tithe because they needed $120,000 to be in the black for the year! I also do their computer work (I still like some of the people there, just not the way the church is run) and they told me they had budgeted $12,000 to upgrade their network! During a pandemic, when that money could have gone to helping families in need and winning souls to Christ.

I don't care much for Western churches for more reasons then this, but this is a pretty big reason. Small churches. Home groups. Teaching others to go start home churches. That's where it's at.

body: Be careful, you're probably thinking of the legendized founders. The real founders were actually pretty strange, Ben Franklin probably murdered someone and hid the body, George Washington owned slaves and passed a law limiting citizenship to white people (and even then only the ones he liked), Thomas Jefferson mutilated his bible, and Alexander Hamilton wanted a monarchy. And Sam Adams was a fucking lunatic who burned down his cousin John Adams's mansion over some argument. And they were almost all freemasons. Not that Britain was any better, they just weren't the godlike men they are portrayed as now (rebellions tend to need sketchy people like that too, Han Solo comes to mind).

body:
In my experience women are actually the *most* uptight and almost legalistic, to the point where it comes off as virtue signaling. Movements like prohibition were led by women for example. I also hear them complaining about abortion and all that 10x more than men talk about it, because it's the "better than thou" attitude. They'll be quick to point out everyone elses' sins while showing off their piety.

However men have their own share of problems and if you're really that afraid of women being in the church I think you'd be quite disappointed in Jesus and the work of the apostle Paul. But I've never seen a church where men are pushed into a back room with no say in anything, if that's really happening where you're at you need to get the heck out of there and find somewhere else.

The church I used to attend is decorated with frilly doilies and flowers, the women have a dozen different events and classes through the week and the last I heard they were ordaining them as pastors. I left a few years ago when we men were relegated to a tiny back room for the men's group while the women had the run of the joint. The thing is, this is the experience I've had at the past few churches I have attended long term and the churches I have visited. Women have been elevated in the chain of command above men, which is not biblical. Women ascribe to "experience" more than men do and are more sympathetic to perceived injustice and slights, ergo, the church has adopted the culture as a baseline for what is right and filters scripture through it where they can. In places where they cannot, ie: really bad sins like murder, they stand, but society as a whole also sees those things as bad. Things like abortion, divorce and adultery get a pass, though, because they are widely accepted by society as a whole, mostly by women, and scripture can be twisted to support them, or ignored where need be.

parent.body:
I think home groups should be where the church is meeting right now, bit unlike when the church began. I know some youtube people don't think "all churches are businesses and want your money", but I think they end up like that. As soon as a church starts to buy property and equipment and take on a staff then keeping money in the coffers becomes a high priority, and Christ can get pushed to the back shelf. And he does, because we see Western churches catering to their best customers! Women! Men don't spend a ton of money on religious stuff. A bible and maybe some studies. Women spend far more AND control where the money goes in a lot of homes. When you pay 10k a month in expenses you need to keep those tithes rolling in! The church I spoke of above once sent out letters urging people to tithe because they needed $120,000 to be in the black for the year! I also do their computer work (I still like some of the people there, just not the way the church is run) and they told me they had budgeted $12,000 to upgrade their network! During a pandemic, when that money could have gone to helping families in need and winning souls to Christ.

I don't care much for Western churches for more reasons then this, but this is a pretty big reason. Small churches. Home groups. Teaching others to go start home churches. That's where it's at.

body:
I'm not "afraid" of women in the church at all, but scripture says they should not be in positions of leadership or teaching in the church both because they are more gullible and because God has ordained an order of authority, with women being under the authority of their fathers and then their husbands. Neither Jesus nor Paul prescribed putting women in either one of those positions and Titus 2 tells older christian women exactly what they SHOULD be teaching the younger generation. Daughters and wives are to ask their husbands for direction on scripture as prescribed in 1 Corinthians (14:35).

Yeah, it was a few different things that got me out of that church. The people were nice, but the adherence to the Word was lacking, as it seems to be much across the country. I left, but still keep in touch with some of the people there.

parent.body:
In my experience women are actually the *most* uptight and almost legalistic, to the point where it comes off as virtue signaling. Movements like prohibition were led by women for example. I also hear them complaining about abortion and all that 10x more than men talk about it, because it's the "better than thou" attitude. They'll be quick to point out everyone elses' sins while showing off their piety.

However men have their own share of problems and if you're really that afraid of women being in the church I think you'd be quite disappointed in Jesus and the work of the apostle Paul. But I've never seen a church where men are pushed into a back room with no say in anything, if that's really happening where you're at you need to get the heck out of there and find somewhere else.

body:
Why do you think women are more gullible? They may be a lot of times but that's usually because people teach them to believe everything they're told because it's assumed they won't be independent or self-sustaining. Both of the "scriptures" you quoted are obvious forgeries added by Roman scribes. Paul didn't write Titus and it doesn't even fit in the chronology of his life, and it teaches numerous heresies. 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 randomly appears smack in the middle of a completely unrelated passage about prophesy and contradicts his other statements, so I think you can put 2 and 2 together. The passage doesn't even make sense with it thrown in there. If you're still not convinced somehow the only "law" it could be referring to is the laws of the Roman empire--indeed, it was illegal for women to speak at a public assembly in Rome. Beyond that there actually manuscript evidence for this one, it has tons of variants and doesn't even appear in the same place half the time, and in two of the oldest manuscripts is marked with a symbol indicating that it wasn't present in some copies. It may have even been translated into greek from the latin version, which had a habit of any time Paul mentioned a wife's name before her husband in a positive light, they changed it to put the husband first. The Romans saw Christianity as a threat to their empire and pagan traditions, no wonder they were this hostile towards it. Here's just a few of Paul's real thoughts:

* 1 Corinthians 7 (direct contradiction of 1 Timothy and Titus which say the only purpose of a woman is to get married and have children, with 1 Timothy even equating their salvation to their bearing of children, which is also a works gospel. It also contradicts the requirement of church officials to be married in Timothy and Titus, which actually disqualify Paul himself as he was unmarried.)

* Galatians 3:28

* Romans 16 (direct contradiction of Titus and 1 Timothy as Phoebe is mentioned as a deacon)

I don't care even if Paul *did* say those things, in the gospels we have Mary Magdelene and several others, not to mention all the examples in the old testament, both of which even include prophets.

Why do you think women are more gullible? They may be a lot of times but that's usually because people teach them to believe everything they're told because it's assumed they won't be independent or self-sustaining. Both of the "scriptures" you quoted are obvious forgeries added by Roman scribes. Paul didn't write Titus and it doesn't even fit in the chronology of his life, and it teaches numerous heresies. 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 randomly appears smack in the middle of a completely unrelated passage about prophesy and contradicts his other statements, so I think you can put 2 and 2 together. The passage doesn't even make sense with it thrown in there. If you're still not convinced somehow the only "law" it could be referring to is the laws of the Roman empire--indeed, it was illegal for women to speak at a public assembly in Rome. Beyond that there actually manuscript evidence for this one, it has tons of variants and doesn't even appear in the same place half the time, and in two of the oldest manuscripts is marked with a symbol indicating that it wasn't present in some copies. It may have even been translated into greek from the latin version, which had a habit of any time Paul mentioned a wife's name before her husband in a positive light, they changed it to put the husband first. The Romans saw Christianity as a threat to their empire and pagan traditions, no wonder they were this hostile towards it. Here's just a few of Paul's real thoughts:

  • 1 Corinthians 7 (direct contradiction of 1 Timothy and Titus which say the only purpose of a woman is to get married and have children, with 1 Timothy even equating their salvation to their bearing of children, which is also a works gospel. It also contradicts the requirement of church officials to be married in Timothy and Titus, which actually disqualify Paul himself as he was unmarried.)

  • Galatians 3:28

  • Romans 16 (direct contradiction of Titus and 1 Timothy as Phoebe is mentioned as a deacon)

I don't care even if Paul did say those things, in the gospels we have Mary Magdelene and several others, not to mention all the examples in the old testament, both of which even include prophets.

body:
Then you and I are an at impasse. Unfortunate, yes, but this seems to be much of the case with online conversation about biblical works. I cannot accept your premise of a tainted bible with regards to certain versions or translations which have been proven out time and time again, so we must part ways on this.

Keep safe. The world is going crazy and we may all get to find out the truth of scripture soon enough, and directly from its author at that.

parent.body:
Why do you think women are more gullible? They may be a lot of times but that's usually because people teach them to believe everything they're told because it's assumed they won't be independent or self-sustaining. Both of the "scriptures" you quoted are obvious forgeries added by Roman scribes. Paul didn't write Titus and it doesn't even fit in the chronology of his life, and it teaches numerous heresies. 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 randomly appears smack in the middle of a completely unrelated passage about prophesy and contradicts his other statements, so I think you can put 2 and 2 together. The passage doesn't even make sense with it thrown in there. If you're still not convinced somehow the only "law" it could be referring to is the laws of the Roman empire--indeed, it was illegal for women to speak at a public assembly in Rome. Beyond that there actually manuscript evidence for this one, it has tons of variants and doesn't even appear in the same place half the time, and in two of the oldest manuscripts is marked with a symbol indicating that it wasn't present in some copies. It may have even been translated into greek from the latin version, which had a habit of any time Paul mentioned a wife's name before her husband in a positive light, they changed it to put the husband first. The Romans saw Christianity as a threat to their empire and pagan traditions, no wonder they were this hostile towards it. Here's just a few of Paul's real thoughts:

* 1 Corinthians 7 (direct contradiction of 1 Timothy and Titus which say the only purpose of a woman is to get married and have children, with 1 Timothy even equating their salvation to their bearing of children, which is also a works gospel. It also contradicts the requirement of church officials to be married in Timothy and Titus, which actually disqualify Paul himself as he was unmarried.)

* Galatians 3:28

* Romans 16 (direct contradiction of Titus and 1 Timothy as Phoebe is mentioned as a deacon)

I don't care even if Paul *did* say those things, in the gospels we have Mary Magdelene and several others, not to mention all the examples in the old testament, both of which even include prophets.

The passage doesn't even make sense with it thrown in there. If you're still not convinced somehow the only "law" it could be referring to is the laws of the Roman empire--indeed, it was illegal for women to speak at a public assembly in Rome. Beyond that there actually manuscript evidence for this one, it has tons of variants and doesn't even appear in the same place half the time, and in two of the oldest manuscripts is marked with a symbol indicating that it wasn't present in some copies.   • 1 Corinthians 7 (direct contradiction of 1 Timothy and Titus which say the only purpose of a woman is to get married and have children, with 1 Timothy even equating their salvation to their bearing of children, which is also a works gospel. body: The truth is that the bible was established in AD 382. By the Council of *Rome*, the very same people who did most of the forgeries, and the biggest criteria was how much they conformed with the catholic church's beliefs at the time. In the first century they only had Jesus and the old testament scriptures, with the ones not spoken directly by God (by word or through prophesy) having the status of "writings good for reading" like the inter-testamental books. And Paul's books were merely letters addressed to churches during his missionary work. This is not my opinion, it is a historical fact. No one before the late 4th century would've known what "The Bible" was, they had a collection of all the separate books, which ones were authentic being regularly disputed until the catholic church "settled" the matter.

"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: A lot of it is more figurative and directed at a particular time and place than the new testament, but it's all people had for millenia. Also the old testament is quoted a lot in the new testament. And guess which version they used.
